question: What force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?

content.source_1: Newton’s law of universal gravitation states that the Sun exerts an attractive force on a planet equal to G·M_sun·m_planet / r^2, directed toward the Sun.
content.source_2: In Newtonian mechanics, any curved trajectory requires an inward (centripetal) acceleration; such acceleration must be provided by a real force, and in a central-mass system the gravitational attraction between the bodies can supply it.
content.source_3: In general relativity, gravity is not a force acting on masses; massive bodies curve spacetime, and freely falling objects move along geodesics with zero proper acceleration.
content.source_4: To a very good approximation, planetary motion around the Sun is free fall in the curved spacetime produced by the Sun’s mass; locally, planets are weightless while orbiting.
content.source_5: The Sun contains about 99.8% of the solar system’s mass, so its influence dominates planetary motion.
content.source_6: Planets have substantial tangential velocities; absent any central influence, a body continues in uniform straight-line motion (Newton’s first law).
